ELIMINATE

How can we cut out the trivial many?  

Think back to the closet metaphor from chapter 1.  

You’ve taken stock of everything in your closet.  

Your clothes are divided into “must keep” and “probably should get rid of.”  

But are you ready to stuff the “probably should get rid of” pile into a bag?  

It’s not enough to determine which activities don’t contribute best.  

You must actively eliminate those that do not contribute.  

Part Three of this book will show you how to eliminate nonessentials.  

You can then make a higher contribution to what is vital.  

You’ll also learn to do this in a way that earns respect.  

Getting rid of old clothes isn’t easy.  

There is a nagging reluctance and fear of regret.  

What if you regret giving away that blazer with big shoulder pads?  

This feeling is normal.  

Studies show we value what we own more than its worth.  

We find it harder to get rid of these items.  

If you’re not ready to part with that blazer, ask this question:  

“If I didn’t own this, how much would I spend to buy it?”  

In life, the killer question for deciding what to eliminate is:  

“If I didn’t have this opportunity, what would I do to acquire it?”  

Finding the discipline to say no to good opportunities is hard.  

But you must find it.  

Remember, failing to say “no” to a nonessential means saying yes by default.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** To make a higher level of contribution, it is essential to actively eliminate nonessential activities and opportunities from your life.
